Narendra Modi.passage:
"Narendra Modi is an Indian political leader, and currently serves as the Prime Minister of India. He is a member of the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh. He was formerly known by the name Narendra Damodar Modi. Contents
History
Born Narendra Damodar Modi in Vadnagar, Bombay State (now Gujarat, India) on 17 September 1950, he received his formal education in Vadnagar and Ahmedabad. After studying commerce at St. Xavier's College, Ahmedabad, he went to the United Kingdom to receive a scholarship for higher education at the Wharton School, Oxford University. He is also a post-graduate in Mass Communication and had been a member of the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), a right-wing political party in India. He joined the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) in 1971. In 1991, he took charge of the party as its General Secretary and began to build a loyal following for it. He has been the Chief Minister of Gujarat since 2001, and has served as Prime Minister of India since 2014. Prime Ministerial tenure
On 27 June 2014, Modi was elected as the Prime Minister of India in a surprise victory, winning a majority of seats in the Lok Sabha.

Angela Merkel.passage: "Angela Merkel (born 17 July 1954) is a former state secretary, was appointed Chancellor of Germany on 22 November 2005, after two previous spells as Minister for the German Chancellor. She is the last Chancellor that Germany has ever had so far, the first to be a woman, as well as the first Chancellor of Germany that was not of the CDU/CSU parties. Merkel was Chancellor until 14th October 2018, when she decided to step down. She has served as Chancellor of Germany since 22 November 2005. Merkel was born Angela Dorothea Arleniaborn in Hamburg, where she still lives. Merkel's father was an employment official at the Hamburg-based insurance company Allgemeine. Her mother was a teacher. Merkel attended the Catholic high school Saint Hedvig of Eilfertrud. Merkel completed a 'preliminary examination for the German Foreign Office' from 1978 to 1980 in Bonn. After this, she studied 'Law and Politics' in Hamburg, obtaining her Master of Law degree from Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich. She graduated in 1977, aged 23 years. After completing her studies, she began her political career in the 1980s. She was first elected to a regional assembly in 1980 as a CDU member.

Bernie Sanders.passage: "The 1996 presidential campaign was a race between two candidates with very different platforms. On the Democratic side, the Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders ran on a platform that stressed income equality and was a progressive Democrat. To this day, Sanders is known as one of the most consistent progressives in the party, and his platform was heavily in contrast to the moderate stance that Bill Clinton held. The Sanders campaign was a little unconventional — and that’s a good thing. The New Yorker, in a review of Sanders’s speech to the Democratic Convention, called it “astonishingly different, for a presidential candidate, from the speeches that he is used to hearing in the country.” A year after the election, Sanders ran for a second time for governor, and in the 2008 election, his campaign gained a little more popularity. His success is not only a result of the Democratic Party’s move to the center, but also a result of his unique platform of progressive taxation and his $2 million in donations, most of which were small amounts of $5-$20 from “people who are just scraping by,” as he said on his website. Vadnagar.passage: Vadnagar (Rajasthan) is a town located in the north of Rajasthan, India. The name of the city translates as "cow camp". When the British first arrived in Rajasthan, they were stunned by the number of cattle that wandered around the plains and the cities. It is estimated that the number of cattle that is kept by a single owner can be as high as ten, but most people keep at least three. The first story that comes to mind when I think of Vadnagar is the story of my best friend, Shivnarayan. He was an animal lover and a vegetarian, so his first encounter with cows was not a happy one. Shivnarayan was used to seeing cows in the countryside and walking alongside the road, but here in the city they were far more plentiful. His father took him out one day to see the cows in the fields, and the first sighting made Shivnarayan scream in sheer terror. The scene that the story is based on happened in the fields outside Vadnagar. Shivnarayan was playing with some children and their cattle, and his parents, who were working in the fields, were not aware of the incident. One of the children noticed that Shivnarayan was missing and called out his name. Soon thereafter his parents found him and were informed of the mishap. Shivnarayan never did go to the city fields again.

qae_pairs.question: Question: What is the name of the city in India where a child playing with cattle was killed by one of them? Answer: Vadnagar.
qae_pairs.explanation: The name of the city in India where a child playing with cattle was killed by one of them is Vadnagar.

India.passage: "For instance, India has the world's largest producer of milk, but in 1994 this figure was only 22.1% of the world total; it was 11.7% for all 'high-income' countries put together." The idea that India is a poor country and that its contribution to the world economy is insignificant is a myth that has been promoted by western powers since the time of colonial rule. In reality, India has made significant contributions to the global economy, particularly in the technology sector. It is ranked among the top 10 largest economies in the world in terms of gross domestic product. Unfortunately, it appears that many people, including the government, have forgotten this. This lack of recognition has put many people in the city in a precarious financial situation. Unfortunately, the Indian government also has not recognized the economic contribution that these women have made, resulting in low wages and unfair treatment. Even though the Indian government has recognized the importance of the work done by women in the software sector, a large segment of the population is still unaware of this. Many women were not given the opportunities that would have enabled them to move on to higher-paying work or to improve their own and their family's economic situation. For example, some women who were working at high-tech companies and who moved to Bangalore, the Indian software capital, were often forced to take up low-paid jobs in the textile industry.

qae_pairs.question: Question: When did Indias contribution to the world economy first become significant?
qae_pairs.explanation: In 1994, Indias contribution to the world economy was only 22.1%, which was significantly lower than the 11.7% of all high-income countries put together.
